Patch Set 1:

Hi Stuart,

I have tried to update the following configuration parameters after applying this patch.
1) filesystem_store_datadir
2) bind_port
3) bind_host
4) workers

In case of filesystem_store_datadir the parameter value changes after reloading the config file, but new image is not created at new location, because the reloaded value of filesystem_store_datadir parameter is not used by newly created child processes.
The reason behind this is, glance_store module is separated from glance and in this configure_add method is called only once when service starts, and not for every api request.

In case of bind_host and bind_host service is not started on new host/port after SIGHUP signal.
IMO, after SIGHUP current children becomes stale_children and new children gets spawned, hence the parent process never gets killed. As the parent process is still bind to previous host and port reloaded bind_host or bind_port value is not used here.

In case of 'workers', its working perfectly.
If there are 2 workers running currently and I change the workers config parameter to 4, before sending SIGHUP signal. Then after service startup on SIGHUP signal, there are 4 workers running.
Similarly I have tested that all existing requests are completed successfully after sending the SIGHUP.

I have tested the same patch with sending multiple requests for about 1 hour and in-between sending SIGHUP signal to parent process at regular interval of 10 minutes. All the requests gets processed successfully.

number of total request send: 228456
number of success requests: 228456
failed requests: 0

I have also tested the patch with enabling SSL for glance-api service.

Thank you.

Patch Set 1:

Hi Abhishek,

Many thanks for some extremely thorough testing :-)

The bind_port/bind_host will not work with this WIP patch -- I don't think I communicated that very clearly -- apologies (it's what I meant with the commit message comment "Handle parent corner cases (eg bind_port)").

The "filesystem_store_datadir" behaviour I didn't anticipate. I see now that glance/cmd/api.py configures these. So I guess it's another parent corner case -- easy enough to handle I hope. I know this is very much of interest to you so I'll push up another patch which handles this shortly.

> number of total request send: 228456 number of success requests: 228456 failed  requests: 0

Awesome!

Thanks again for your great input.

Patch Set 1:

Whats the thoughts on getting this into oslo as an update there?

Patch Set 1:

> Whats the thoughts on getting this into oslo as an update there?

Hi Joshua, thanks for your comment. So that has been in the back of my mind -- it's great that someone else thinks it may be worth looking at!

What I'm thinking is first: complete (merge) this Glance specific patch (there's still quite a bit of work left here), second: go to the mailing list to poll who thinks bringing this style of behaviour to oslo's Launcher makes sense. (Or might that be a summit topic?)

I think ideally this would eventually go into Oslo and then Glance would switch to importing that. I am keen to get it working in Glance first though (just to get viable code out there more quickly, eg for the NTT specific use case).

Note the dependency on a (small) eventlet change getting merged.
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

Hi Stuart,

I have tested following scenarios with Filesystem store parameters:

1. change filesystem_store_datadir
2. change filesystem_store_datadirs
3. change filesystem_store_datadir and filesystem_store_datadirs both at same time

In first two cases I have observed that values are reloaded correctly on SIGHUP and the image is getting added at the new location.

In 3 case where I am changing both filesystem_store_datadir and filesystem_store_datadirs at same time, after sending SIGHUP when I hit create-image api, it's giving HTTP 500 error (StoreAddDisabled exception). This is because, either filesystem_store_datadir or filesystem_store_datadirs option can be used for file system store.

For first two scenarios every thing is working as per expectation.

Thank you!!

Patch Set 3:

Stuart,
Swift handles this similarly, but with a slight difference.  When a Swift server gets a SIGHUP, it immediately relinquishes its listen socket and exits.  All of its old children continue processing their in-flight requests but don't accept any new ones.  Then a new server is started up which reads in any changed config.  That dance is made easier with the Manager class and the swift-init CLI tool.

I'm not saying it's a better approach, but it does solve some of the problems here (changes in bind_port, no upstream eventlet changes needed).  It does have the trade-off that there's a brief window during which *new* connections can't start due to there being no listen socket until the fresh server is started.

Anyway, just sayin' Swift's strategy is worth examining as a similar way of doing the same thing, even if you don't want to take on those particular trade-offs.

Relevant code is swift.common.manager.Manager, bin/swift-init, swift.common.wsgi.run_wsgi

Cheers,
Darrell
Uploaded patch set 4.
Uploaded patch set 5.

Patch Set 5:

@Darrell

Thanks for the input!

I did look at swift (and a few other strategies). Swift is nice in that it allows reloading a new binary, but does not offer zero downtime. I personally liked this aspect of the nginx strategy. (And it's pretty neat when you test it!)

The eventlet changed has merged so that's less of an issue now too I think.
